p: In a European study, a rapid upsurge of HCV incidence among human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)‐positive men who have sex with men (MSM) was observed, from 0.09 per 100 person‐years in 1990 to 2.34 per 100 person‐years in 2007 [ 6]. Epidemiologically HCV is a common co‐infection in HIV‐positive persons as the two infections share a similar route of transmission. HIV‐associated immunodeficiency increases the susceptibility of the host to HCV entry and contributes to the subsequent failure of virus clearance [ 7]. Among MSM, engagement in unprotected anal intercourse has increased the risk of virus transmission [ 8]. The synergy of biological and behavioural risk factor has predisposed HIV‐positive MSM to an increased susceptibility to HCV infection.
